🐐 𝑮𝑶𝑨𝑻. 𝑴𝑬𝑺𝑺𝑰. https://t.co/9BiosHsOO4 🚨 ATTENTION!: Last day of voting for #MVPMovistar!

🔁 Each RT is a vote so you know what you have to do 😜 ⬇️ https://t.co/fuQnNvH3kO Want to learn more about Messi's time as an FC Barcelona youth player? 👀

👉 https://t.co/U2mCoqrCoZ https://t.co/lajVeAjWFs 🥇🇦🇷 In the summer of 2005, the world took notice: he won the U20 World Cup with his country, where he was top scorer (6 goals) and MVP. A few weeks later, his performance in the Gamper against Juventus was praised all around the planet 😍 
The rest… is history 🐐 https://t.co/M963GJYorC In 2004/05 he alternated between Barça B and the first team. He made his competitive debut against Espanyol and scored his first goal against Albacete at the Camp Nou ✨⚽ https://t.co/nXZzxLJA2h That same season he also started playing for Barça C and Barça B, making 37 official appearances and scoring 35 goals. He also won the league with the U18B team and played for the 🇦🇷 U20 national team👏 https://t.co/h7ZK7edF6W 🔥 Then in the 2003/04 season, Leo played for as many as 5⃣ teams.
He started with U18B, but quickly got called up to U18A and when he was still only 16, Rijkaard gave him his senior debut in a friendly against Mourinho's FC Porto https://t.co/vdm4g79Uyi 🏆🏆 The team won the league and Copa Catalunya!
In the final, Messi had a broken cheekbone and had to play with protection, but took it off after 7 minutes because he couldn't breathe properly. He'd scored twice by half-time and Barça eventually beat Espanyol 4-1 🙌 https://t.co/xZ7bPtOE0J The following year with the U16A team, Messi scored 38 goals in 31 games, including nine braces and four hat-tricks and once he scored four times! But it wasn't just the goals. It was the kind of goals and, most of all, the way he played 😍 https://t.co/VmojGE69i1 💪 It took him months to recover from the injury, but the following season he trained with the U14A team, and quickly earned promotion to the U16B team coached by Tito Vilanova
He faced another months-long wait due to red tape, but eventually played 10 games and scored 9 goals 🔥 https://t.co/aOfVjbLoPG But Messi made his debut with the U14B team. Barça won 3-0 at Amposta and he scored one of the goals ⚽
But things took a nasty turn in his second game. He fractured his fibula and missed the rest of the season 🤕 https://t.co/uBoYlUXkHV 🇦🇷 ✈ Leo was only 12 when he came to Barça from Argentina, and although he trained with the U14A team, there was red tape to sort out before he could make his debut. The day finally arrived on 7 April 2001... https://t.co/NV3l8Kj05t 🎂 Messi is 33 today and well established as the greatest player in the world
🏆 34 major trophies
⚽ 629 goals for Barça
👕 722 appearances for Barça
🥇 6 Ballons d'Or
👟 6 Golden Shoes

Days. #WallpaperWednesday https://t.co/OOslPvfuJn Where have we seen this before? 🤔 #Messi https://t.co/GfppCktuiW If you want to learn more about László Kubala, one of Barça's greatest legends, check out the documentary 'Kubala, The Day A Legend Was Born.'

🎥: https://t.co/ZveOqxU1sj

(10/10) ⬆️ https://t.co/nr87NF1rBt László Kubala died in Barcelona on May 17th, 2002. 

Today, everyone who visits Camp Nou can see his statue, which has stood in front of the stadium since September 24th, 2009.

(9/10) ↕️ https://t.co/42R5s6YnlH In all, Kubala played 357 games for Barça and scored 281 goals.

Later, he would go on to have two stints as Barça manager (1961-63 and in 1980), in addition to time coaching other clubs  and three national teams, including Spain and Paraguay.

(8/10) ↕️ https://t.co/tgtZIrh5s8 In 11 seasons with Barça (1950-61), Kubala won a staggering 14 titles, and could have won more had he not suffered various injuries, including a bout with tuberculosis in 1952.

4️⃣x @LaLigaEN
1️⃣x Latin Cup
2️⃣x Inter-Cities Fairs Cup
5️⃣x Spanish Cup
2️⃣x Copa Eva Duarte

(7/10) ↕️ https://t.co/rwXQr1LKlw But beyond all those qualities, Kubala was an innate goalscorer. He still holds the Club's single-game scoring record in @LaLigaEN, from when he found the net seven (7) times in a 9-0 Barça win over @RealSporting in 1952.

But, how many titles did he win with Barça?

(6/10) ↕️ https://t.co/a2W2ZGFPlm Kubala stood out for his sheer physical strength. He was incredibly gifted with his feet, boasted extraordinary field vision, was a free-kick master, and was a highly respected leader on the field.

(5/10) ↕️ https://t.co/Ylo6XBbRvv Barça's dominance could have been even greater if it had not been for the unsuccessful effort to sign Alfredo Di Stéfano in 1953, which kept the team from bringing together to the two greatest stars of the era.

(4/10) ↕️ https://t.co/HUsVbLKmcm Although Kubala signed with Barça in June of 1950, he didn't make his official debut until April of 1951 due to bureaucratic red tape.

His arrival ushered in a golden age for Barça, helping the team win everything, including the Five Cups from 1951-1953.

(3/10) ↕️ https://t.co/qckuqFH0Jz Born of Slovakian parents in Budapest, Hungary, Kubala caught the interest of Josep Samitier, Barça's Technical Secretary at the time, during a tour of Spain by the Hungary national team, founded by Kubala and other players who were refugees from Eastern countries.

(2/10) ↕️ https://t.co/YbpJ6LAX9t Born #OnThisDay, 93 years ago, he is considered one of the great legends in Barça history. He was a global reference point in the world of football in the 1950s. June 15th will mark 70 years since he signed with Barça.

We're talking about László Kubala.
